name: Introduction to Geography and Geographic Inquiry
short_description: Students explore the five themes of geography, understand the importance of location and place, and develop foundational skills in using geographic tools and thinking spatially about the world.

sub_topics.name: Five Themes of Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding location, place, human-environment interaction, movement, and region as organizing frameworks for geographic study.

sub_topics.name: Absolute and Relative Location
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn to identify and describe locations using coordinates and spatial relationships to other places.
example_tasks: Identify the absolute location of your school using latitude and longitude coordinates to the nearest degree
Describe the relative location of three major U.S. cities using directional terms and distances from your hometown
Compare how absolute and relative location are used differently by giving examples of when each type is most useful
Plot five world capitals on a world map using their latitude and longitude coordinates and explain their hemispheric positions

sub_topics.name: Physical and Human Characteristics of Place
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing what makes locations unique through their physical features and human-created characteristics.
example_tasks: List three physical characteristics and three human characteristics that make your community unique
Compare the physical and human characteristics of two different regions such as the Great Plains and the Rocky Mountains
Create a concept map showing how physical characteristics of a place influence its human characteristics
Analyze how the physical characteristics of New Orleans have influenced its culture, economy, and challenges

sub_topics.name: Human-Environment Interaction
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how humans adapt to, modify, and depend on their environment.
example_tasks: Identify three ways people in your region have adapted to the local climate and terrain
Analyze how the construction of the Hoover Dam modified the environment and impacted surrounding communities
Compare how people in Alaska versus Florida adapt to their different environmental conditions
Evaluate both positive and negative effects of human modifications to the environment in your state

sub_topics.name: Movement and Spatial Interaction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the movement of people, goods, ideas, and information across space.
example_tasks: Trace the journey of a product from your home, identifying at least five places it moved through to reach you
Create a diagram showing different types of movement (people, goods, ideas) between two countries
Analyze how the internet has changed the movement of information compared to 50 years ago
Map the migration patterns of your family or interview someone about their family's movement over generations

sub_topics.name: Formal, Functional, and Vernacular Regions
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between different types of regions based on uniform characteristics, functions, or perceptions.
example_tasks: Identify whether the Midwest, the Dallas-Fort Worth area, and Silicon Valley are formal, functional, or vernacular regions
Draw and label a functional region centered on your school, showing the area from which students travel
Create a map of vernacular regions in the United States and explain how they are defined by cultural perception
Compare formal regions defined by climate with vernacular regions defined by cultural identity in the same area

sub_topics.name: Geographic Tools and Technologies
sub_topics.short_description: Developing proficiency with maps, globes, GPS, GIS, and other technologies used to collect and analyze geographic information.

sub_topics.name: Maps and Globes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the purposes, advantages, and limitations of different geographic representations.
example_tasks: Explain three advantages of using a globe and three advantages of using a map for geographic study
Identify which type of map (political, physical, thematic) would be best for answering five different geographic questions
Compare how the same area appears on a globe versus a flat map and explain the differences
Analyze why all flat maps have some distortion and describe the trade-offs map makers face

sub_topics.name: Map Elements and Reading Skills
sub_topics.short_description: Using title, legend, scale, compass rose, and other map features to interpret geographic information.
example_tasks: Use the scale on a road map to calculate the actual distance between three cities in your state
Interpret a thematic map's legend to answer questions about population density patterns
Create your own map of your neighborhood including all essential map elements
Compare how the same data appears on maps with different scales and explain how scale affects the map's usefulness

sub_topics.name: Latitude and Longitude System
sub_topics.short_description: Mastering the coordinate system used to locate any point on Earth's surface with precision.
example_tasks: Plot six locations on a world map when given their latitude and longitude coordinates
Determine the coordinates of five major world cities using a latitude-longitude grid
Explain why lines of latitude are parallel while lines of longitude converge at the poles
Calculate the approximate distance between two locations using their latitude coordinates and knowledge that one degree equals about 69 miles

sub_topics.name: GPS and Digital Mapping Technologies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Global Positioning Systems and digital mapping tools work and their applications in modern geography.
example_tasks: Explain how GPS uses satellites to determine location and describe three everyday uses of GPS technology
Compare traditional paper maps with digital maps like Google Maps, listing advantages and disadvantages of each
Use an online mapping tool to plan a route between two cities and analyze different route options
Describe how GPS technology has changed navigation, emergency response, and other fields in the past 20 years

sub_topics.name: Spatial Thinking and Geographic Inquiry
sub_topics.short_description: Developing the ability to think about space, patterns, and relationships, and to ask and answer geographic questions systematically.

sub_topics.name: Asking Geographic Questions
sub_topics.short_description: Formulating questions about where things are located, why they are there, and what the implications are.
example_tasks: Transform three non-geographic questions into geographic questions by adding where, why there, or what impact elements
Generate five geographic questions about a current event in the news that could be investigated with maps and data
Analyze a geographic issue in your community and create three levels of questions (basic, analytical, evaluative)
Practice asking 'where', 'why there', and 'so what' questions about patterns you observe on a thematic map

sub_topics.name: Recognizing Spatial Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and describing patterns in the distribution of human and physical features across space.
example_tasks: Examine a map of U.S. population distribution and describe three patterns you observe
Compare the spatial patterns of rainfall and agriculture in the United States and explain the relationship
Identify clustering, dispersal, or linear patterns in the location of businesses along a local street
Analyze a map showing earthquake locations and describe the spatial pattern and what it reveals about Earth's structure

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Spatial Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how features in different locations are connected and influence each other.
example_tasks: Explain the relationship between the location of major cities and rivers in the United States
Analyze how distance from the ocean affects the climate of different regions
Investigate the spatial relationship between population density and agricultural land use in your state
Examine how proximity to natural resources has influenced the location of industries in a region

sub_topics.name: Geographic Inquiry Process
sub_topics.short_description: Following systematic steps to investigate geographic questions using data collection, analysis, and interpretation.
example_tasks: Design a geographic inquiry project: formulate a question, identify needed data sources, and plan analysis methods
Collect data about land use in your neighborhood through observation and organize it in a data table
Analyze population data for your state over time and create a graph showing trends
Present findings from a geographic investigation including maps, data, and conclusions about a local issue

name: Earth's Physical Systems
short_description: Students examine the structure of Earth, plate tectonics, and the formation of landforms through geological processes, understanding how the planet's physical features have developed and continue to change over time.

sub_topics.name: Earth's Structure and Composition
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the layers of Earth from the inner core to the crust and how they interact.

sub_topics.name: Earth's Layers
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the characteristics of the inner core, outer core, mantle, and crust.
example_tasks: Create a labeled cross-section diagram of Earth showing the four main layers and their relative thicknesses
Compare the temperature, composition, and state of matter (solid/liquid) of each of Earth's layers
Explain how scientists have learned about Earth's interior structure without being able to dig to the center
Analyze why the inner core is solid while the outer core is liquid despite the inner core being hotter

sub_topics.name: Lithosphere and Types of Crust
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between oceanic and continental crust and understanding the lithosphere's role in plate tectonics.
example_tasks: Create a comparison table showing differences between oceanic crust and continental crust in thickness, density, and composition
Explain why oceanic crust is denser than continental crust and what this means for plate interactions
Draw a diagram showing how the lithosphere differs from the crust and includes part of the upper mantle
Analyze why continental crust is typically older than oceanic crust

sub_topics.name: Plate Tectonics Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring the theory of plate tectonics and how the movement of Earth's lithospheric plates shapes the planet's surface.

sub_topics.name: Continental Drift and Evidence
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Alfred Wegener's hypothesis and the evidence supporting the movement of continents over time.
example_tasks: List four pieces of evidence that Alfred Wegener used to support his continental drift hypothesis
Analyze how the shapes of South America and Africa support the idea that they were once connected
Examine fossil evidence showing the same species on continents now separated by oceans
Explain why Wegener's hypothesis was initially rejected and what new evidence eventually supported it

sub_topics.name: Seafloor Spreading
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how new oceanic crust forms at mid-ocean ridges and spreads outward.
example_tasks: Describe the process of seafloor spreading at a mid-ocean ridge using a labeled diagram
Explain how magnetic striping on the ocean floor provides evidence for seafloor spreading
Calculate the rate of seafloor spreading if two points 100 km apart have rocks that differ in age by 2 million years
Analyze why the oldest oceanic crust is found farthest from mid-ocean ridges

sub_topics.name: Types of Plate Boundaries
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying divergent, convergent, and transform boundaries and the geologic features associated with each.
example_tasks: Create a three-column chart comparing divergent, convergent, and transform boundaries including examples of each
Identify the type of plate boundary responsible for forming the Himalaya Mountains and explain the process
Explain why the Mid-Atlantic Ridge is a divergent boundary and describe what happens there
Analyze the San Andreas Fault as a transform boundary and predict the types of geologic hazards it produces

sub_topics.name: Convection and Plate Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how convection currents in the mantle drive the movement of tectonic plates.
example_tasks: Draw a diagram showing how convection currents in the mantle cause plates to move
Explain the relationship between heat from Earth's core, mantle convection, and plate movement
Compare convection in the mantle to convection in boiling water or air currents
Predict what would happen to plate tectonics if Earth's interior cooled completely

sub_topics.name: Volcanic Activity and Landforms
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how volcanoes form, the types of volcanic eruptions, and the landforms created by volcanic activity.

sub_topics.name: How Volcanoes Form
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the processes that create volcanoes at plate boundaries and hot spots.
example_tasks: Explain how volcanoes form at convergent boundaries where one plate subducts beneath another
Describe how the Hawaiian Islands formed over a hot spot in the middle of a plate
Create a map showing the Ring of Fire and explain why so many volcanoes are located there
Compare volcano formation at divergent boundaries (like Iceland) versus convergent boundaries (like Mt. St. Helens)

sub_topics.name: Types of Volcanoes
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between shield volcanoes, composite volcanoes, and cinder cone volcanoes based on their characteristics.
example_tasks: Create a comparison chart of shield, composite, and cinder cone volcanoes including shape, lava type, and eruption style
Identify whether Mt. Kilauea, Mt. Fuji, and Paricutin are shield, composite, or cinder cone volcanoes and explain why
Explain why shield volcanoes have gentle slopes while composite volcanoes have steep slopes
Analyze which type of volcano is most dangerous to nearby communities and justify your answer

sub_topics.name: Volcanic Hazards and Benefits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the dangers volcanoes pose and the benefits they provide to humans and ecosystems.
example_tasks: List five hazards associated with volcanic eruptions and rank them by potential danger to human life
Explain why volcanic ash can be dangerous to aircraft and how it affects agriculture
Describe three benefits that volcanic activity provides, such as fertile soil or geothermal energy
Analyze why millions of people choose to live near active volcanoes despite the risks

sub_topics.name: Earthquakes and Seismic Activity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how and why earthquakes occur, how they are measured, and their effects on the landscape and human populations.

sub_topics.name: Causes of Earthquakes
sub_topics.short_description: Explaining how stress and strain along faults cause earthquakes when rocks suddenly break or slip.
example_tasks: Describe what happens along a fault line when stress builds up until rocks break, causing an earthquake
Explain why earthquakes are more common along plate boundaries than in the middle of plates
Identify the focus and epicenter of an earthquake and explain the difference between them
Analyze a map of earthquake locations worldwide and explain the pattern you observe

sub_topics.name: Measuring Earthquakes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding seismographs, the Richter and Moment Magnitude scales, and the Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale.
example_tasks: Explain how a seismograph works to detect and record earthquake waves
Compare the Richter scale and Moment Magnitude scale, explaining what each measures
Interpret a seismograph reading to determine when an earthquake occurred and estimate its distance
Use the Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale to describe the effects of earthquakes of different magnitudes on buildings and people

sub_topics.name: Earthquake Hazards and Preparedness
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying earthquake hazards and understanding how communities can prepare for and respond to seismic events.
example_tasks: List five hazards caused by earthquakes including both direct effects and secondary hazards like tsunamis
Create an earthquake preparedness plan for your school or home including before, during, and after actions
Explain how building codes in earthquake-prone areas like California differ from those in stable regions
Analyze why some earthquakes cause more damage than others, considering magnitude, depth, and location

sub_topics.name: Landform Development and Mountain Building
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how various landforms are created through tectonic processes, weathering, and erosion.

sub_topics.name: Mountain Building Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how mountains form through folding, faulting, and volcanic activity.
example_tasks: Explain how the Himalaya Mountains formed when the Indian plate collided with the Eurasian plate
Compare fold mountains, fault-block mountains, and volcanic mountains, giving examples of each
Create a model or diagram showing how compression causes rock layers to fold into mountains
Analyze why the Rocky Mountains and Appalachian Mountains have different characteristics despite both being fold mountains

sub_topics.name: Weathering and Erosion
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between weathering and erosion and understanding how they shape landforms over time.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between weathering and erosion using specific examples of each process
Describe three types of mechanical weathering and three types of chemical weathering
Analyze how the Grand Canyon was formed through the erosion of the Colorado River over millions of years
Compare the effects of weathering and erosion in different climates, such as deserts versus humid regions

sub_topics.name: Agents of Erosion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how water, wind, ice, and gravity shape the Earth's surface through erosion and deposition.
example_tasks: Identify landforms created by water erosion such as valleys, canyons, and river deltas
Explain how glaciers have shaped landforms in North America, creating features like the Great Lakes
Describe how wind erosion creates sand dunes in desert regions
Analyze before and after photos of a coastline to identify erosion patterns and predict future changes

sub_topics.name: Depositional Landforms
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying landforms created when eroded materials are deposited in new locations.
example_tasks: Explain how river deltas form when sediment is deposited at a river's mouth
Describe the formation of moraines, drumlins, and other glacial depositional features
Identify how beaches and barrier islands form through deposition of sediment by waves and currents
Analyze aerial photographs to identify depositional landforms and explain the processes that created them

name: Climate and Weather Systems
short_description: Students investigate the difference between weather and climate, analyze factors that influence climate patterns, and explore the major climate zones of the world and their characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Distinguishing Weather and Climate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between short-term weather conditions and long-term climate patterns.

sub_topics.name: Definitions and Characteristics
sub_topics.short_description: Defining weather as short-term atmospheric conditions and climate as long-term patterns over 30+ years.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between weather and climate using examples from your local area
Determine whether each of the following statements describes weather or climate: 'It is raining today' and 'This region receives 40 inches of rain annually'
Describe your local climate using temperature and precipitation patterns, then describe today's weather
Analyze why climate is more useful than weather for planning agriculture and infrastructure

sub_topics.name: Elements of Weather
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and measuring temperature, precipitation, wind, humidity, and air pressure as components of weather.
example_tasks: Record daily weather observations for a week including temperature, precipitation, wind direction, and cloud cover
Explain how meteorologists use barometric pressure changes to predict weather
Interpret weather symbols on a weather map to describe current conditions in different regions
Compare the weather elements of two different days and explain what caused the differences

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Climate
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how latitude, elevation, proximity to water, ocean currents, and wind patterns influence regional climates.

sub_topics.name: Latitude and Solar Energy Distribution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the angle of the sun's rays varies with latitude, creating temperature differences from equator to poles.
example_tasks: Explain why regions near the equator are warmer than regions near the poles using diagrams of sun angle
Compare the average annual temperatures of cities at different latitudes and explain the pattern
Describe how the tilt of Earth's axis affects the amount of solar energy different latitudes receive
Analyze why tropical regions have less seasonal temperature variation than middle latitudes

sub_topics.name: Elevation and Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how temperature decreases with increasing elevation and affects local climate.
example_tasks: Calculate the expected temperature change if you climb from sea level to 3,000 feet elevation using the lapse rate
Explain why Denver, Colorado, has cooler temperatures than cities at the same latitude but lower elevation
Describe how elevation affects climate zones on mountains, creating different ecosystems at different heights
Analyze climate data from cities at different elevations in the same region to identify the elevation effect

sub_topics.name: Proximity to Water Bodies
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how oceans and large lakes moderate temperature and increase precipitation in coastal areas.
example_tasks: Compare the annual temperature range of a coastal city with an inland city at the same latitude and explain the difference
Explain why coastal areas have milder winters and cooler summers than interior regions
Describe the lake effect snow phenomenon and identify regions affected by it
Analyze climate data to determine which cities are coastal versus inland based on temperature patterns

sub_topics.name: Ocean Currents and Climate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how warm and cold ocean currents affect the climate of nearby coastal regions.
example_tasks: Explain how the Gulf Stream affects the climate of Western Europe, making it warmer than expected for its latitude
Compare the climates of the east and west coasts of continents, relating differences to ocean currents
Identify warm and cold ocean currents on a world map and predict their effects on adjacent land areas
Analyze why San Francisco has cooler summers than cities at similar latitudes on the East Coast

sub_topics.name: Prevailing Winds and Mountain Barriers
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how wind patterns and mountain ranges create rain shadows and affect precipitation distribution.
example_tasks: Draw a diagram showing how a rain shadow forms on the leeward side of a mountain range
Explain why the western side of the Cascade Mountains receives much more precipitation than the eastern side
Describe how the prevailing westerlies affect climate patterns in the middle latitudes
Analyze a precipitation map of a mountainous region to identify windward and leeward sides

sub_topics.name: World Climate Zones and Regions
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and describing the major climate zones using the Köppen classification system and understanding their characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Tropical Climates
sub_topics.short_description: Examining tropical wet, tropical wet and dry, and tropical monsoon climates found near the equator.
example_tasks: Describe the temperature and precipitation characteristics of tropical rainforest climates
Compare tropical wet climates (like the Amazon) with tropical wet and dry climates (like the African savanna)
Explain why tropical regions have warm temperatures year-round with little seasonal variation
Identify regions on a world map that have tropical climates and explain why they are located where they are

sub_topics.name: Dry Climates (Arid and Semiarid)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the characteristics of desert and steppe climates and their global distribution.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between arid (desert) and semiarid (steppe) climates in terms of precipitation
Describe the characteristics of hot deserts like the Sahara versus cold deserts like the Gobi
Identify factors that cause deserts to form, including rain shadows, cold ocean currents, and distance from moisture sources
Analyze a climograph (climate graph) to determine whether it represents an arid or semiarid climate

sub_topics.name: Temperate Climates
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring Mediterranean, humid subtropical, marine west coast, and humid continental climates in the middle latitudes.
example_tasks: Compare the four main types of temperate climates, describing their temperature and precipitation patterns
Explain why Mediterranean climates have wet winters and dry summers
Identify which type of temperate climate characterizes your region and describe its seasonal patterns
Analyze why humid continental climates have greater seasonal temperature variation than marine west coast climates

sub_topics.name: Continental and Polar Climates
sub_topics.short_description: Examining subarctic, tundra, and ice cap climates in high latitudes and their extreme conditions.
example_tasks: Describe the characteristics of subarctic climates including very cold winters and short, cool summers
Explain the difference between tundra climates and ice cap climates
Identify regions with polar climates on a world map and explain why few people live there permanently
Compare the challenges of living in subarctic climates like interior Alaska versus temperate climates

sub_topics.name: Highland Climates
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how elevation creates varied climates in mountainous regions regardless of latitude.
example_tasks: Explain how climate changes with elevation in mountain regions, creating different zones
Describe the climate zones found on a mountain in the tropics from base to peak
Compare highland climates in the Rockies with those in the Andes, identifying similarities and differences
Analyze why highland areas can have climates very different from the surrounding lowlands at the same latitude

sub_topics.name: Climate Data Analysis and Interpretation
sub_topics.short_description: Developing skills to read and interpret climographs, analyze climate data, and make predictions about climate patterns.

sub_topics.name: Reading and Interpreting Climographs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how to read climate graphs showing temperature and precipitation data over a year.
example_tasks: Read a climograph for a city and identify the warmest and coolest months, wettest and driest months
Compare climographs of three different cities and determine which climate zone each represents
Create a climograph for your own city using temperature and precipitation data
Analyze climographs to identify patterns such as seasonal precipitation or temperature ranges

sub_topics.name: Comparing Climate Regions
sub_topics.short_description: Using climate data to compare different regions and explain variations.
example_tasks: Compare the climate characteristics of Miami, Florida, and Seattle, Washington, using data tables
Explain why two cities at similar latitudes can have very different climates
Analyze climate data to determine which factors most strongly influence a region's climate
Use climate data to predict agricultural potential and settlement patterns in different regions

sub_topics.name: Climate Classification Skills
sub_topics.short_description: Applying climate classification criteria to categorize locations into climate zones.
example_tasks: Given temperature and precipitation data for a location, classify it using the Köppen climate classification
Create a decision tree or flowchart for classifying climates based on temperature and precipitation criteria
Classify five different cities into climate zones based on provided climate data
Explain which climate characteristics are most important for distinguishing between similar climate types

name: Water Systems and Hydrosphere
short_description: Students explore the water cycle, distribution of freshwater and saltwater, major water systems including rivers and oceans, and the importance of water resources for human activities and ecosystems.

sub_topics.name: The Water Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the continuous movement of water through evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and runoff.

sub_topics.name: Components of the Water Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and describing evaporation, condensation, precipitation, infiltration, and runoff processes.
example_tasks: Create a labeled diagram of the water cycle showing all major processes and water reservoirs
Explain how energy from the sun drives the water cycle through evaporation
Describe what happens to precipitation after it falls, including infiltration and runoff paths
Trace the journey of a water molecule through the complete water cycle from ocean to atmosphere to land and back

sub_topics.name: Water Storage Reservoirs
sub_topics.short_description: Examining where water is stored on Earth including oceans, ice caps, groundwater, lakes, and atmosphere.
example_tasks: Create a pie chart showing the distribution of Earth's water among oceans, ice, groundwater, and other reservoirs
Explain why only about 2.5% of Earth's water is freshwater and why most of that is inaccessible
Compare the residence time of water in different reservoirs from the atmosphere (days) to glaciers (thousands of years)
Analyze why groundwater is such an important freshwater source for human use

sub_topics.name: Human Impacts on the Water Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how human activities such as deforestation, urbanization, and dam construction affect the water cycle.
example_tasks: Explain how urbanization increases runoff and decreases infiltration compared to natural landscapes
Describe how deforestation affects evapotranspiration rates and local precipitation patterns
Analyze the effects of building dams on river systems and the water cycle downstream
Evaluate how irrigation for agriculture affects local water tables and groundwater availability

sub_topics.name: Rivers and Watersheds
sub_topics.short_description: Examining river systems, drainage basins, and the role of rivers in shaping landscapes and supporting human activities.

sub_topics.name: River System Components
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tributaries, main channels, mouth, source, and how rivers change from headwaters to mouth.
example_tasks: Label the parts of a river system including source, tributaries, main channel, and mouth on a diagram
Explain how rivers change in width, depth, velocity, and sediment load from headwaters to mouth
Trace the Mississippi River from its source in Minnesota to its mouth in Louisiana, identifying major tributaries
Compare mountain rivers (steep, fast-flowing) with rivers in plains (wider, slower) in terms of erosion and deposition

sub_topics.name: Watersheds and Drainage Basins
sub_topics.short_description: Defining watersheds as areas where all precipitation drains to a common outlet and understanding their boundaries.
example_tasks: Define watershed and explain why activities in one part of a watershed can affect water quality downstream
Identify the watershed you live in and trace where water from your area ultimately flows
Draw or outline a watershed on a topographic map by identifying divides based on elevation
Compare the sizes of major U.S. watersheds like the Mississippi, Columbia, and Colorado River basins

sub_topics.name: River Processes and Landforms
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how rivers erode, transport, and deposit sediment, creating various landforms.
example_tasks: Explain how rivers erode their channels through hydraulic action, abrasion, and solution
Describe the formation of river features such as waterfalls, meanders, oxbow lakes, and deltas
Analyze why rivers form meanders (curves) in flat terrain rather than flowing in straight lines
Identify erosional and depositional landforms on aerial photographs or maps of river systems

sub_topics.name: Flooding and Floodplains
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why floods occur, their impacts, and the characteristics of floodplains.
example_tasks: Explain natural causes of flooding including heavy rainfall, snowmelt, and storm surges
Describe why floodplains are both hazardous for development and attractive for agriculture
Analyze a flood risk map to identify areas at greatest risk during different flood levels
Evaluate the pros and cons of building levees and other flood control structures on rivers

sub_topics.name: Rivers and Human Use
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how humans use rivers for transportation, water supply, power generation, and recreation.
example_tasks: List five ways humans use rivers and explain why so many cities are located on rivers
Explain how dams on rivers provide benefits like hydroelectric power but also create environmental challenges
Analyze how the role of rivers in transportation has changed from the past to the present
Investigate a conflict over water rights for a major river system like the Colorado River

sub_topics.name: Oceans and Marine Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring ocean basins, ocean currents, tides, and the critical role oceans play in climate and ecosystems.

sub_topics.name: Ocean Basins and Features
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the major oceans and understanding seafloor features like continental shelves, trenches, and mid-ocean ridges.
example_tasks: Name and locate the five major oceans on a world map, identifying which are largest and deepest
Describe the major features of the ocean floor including continental shelves, slopes, abyssal plains, and trenches
Explain how mid-ocean ridges form and their role in seafloor spreading
Compare the depth of ocean trenches like the Mariana Trench to the height of major mountains

sub_topics.name: Ocean Currents and Circulation Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding surface and deep ocean currents and their effects on climate and marine ecosystems.
example_tasks: Identify major surface currents like the Gulf Stream and California Current on a world map
Explain how wind patterns, Earth's rotation, and continental barriers influence ocean current patterns
Describe the global conveyor belt of deep ocean circulation and its importance for climate regulation
Analyze how warm and cold ocean currents affect the climate of coastal regions they pass

sub_topics.name: Tides and Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what causes tides and waves and their effects on coastlines.
example_tasks: Explain how the gravitational pull of the moon and sun causes tides
Describe the difference between spring tides and neap tides
Explain how waves form due to wind and how they erode coastlines
Analyze tide tables to determine the time and height of high and low tides for a specific location

sub_topics.name: Ocean Resources and Human Use
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how humans use oceans for food, transportation, energy, and recreation, and associated challenges.
example_tasks: List five resources humans obtain from oceans including fish, minerals, and energy
Explain the importance of oceans for global trade and transportation
Describe challenges facing ocean ecosystems such as overfishing, pollution, and acidification
Analyze the economic importance of coastal tourism and fishing industries

sub_topics.name: Groundwater and Aquifers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how groundwater forms, aquifer systems, and the importance of groundwater as a freshwater resource.

sub_topics.name: Groundwater Formation and Storage
sub_topics.short_description: Explaining how water infiltrates soil and rock to become groundwater stored in aquifers.
example_tasks: Describe the process of infiltration and percolation as water moves underground
Explain the difference between the unsaturated zone and the saturated zone below the water table
Define aquifer and describe the characteristics of rocks that make good aquifers
Identify permeable and impermeable layers on a cross-section diagram of underground geology

sub_topics.name: Wells and Groundwater Extraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how wells access groundwater and issues related to over-extraction.
example_tasks: Explain how a well is drilled to reach the water table and extract groundwater
Describe what causes a cone of depression to form around a pumping well
Analyze the problem of groundwater depletion in regions like the Ogallala Aquifer
Evaluate the consequences of excessive groundwater pumping including subsidence and saltwater intrusion

sub_topics.name: Groundwater Quality and Contamination
sub_topics.short_description: Examining threats to groundwater quality and the challenges of cleaning contaminated aquifers.
example_tasks: List sources of groundwater contamination including agricultural runoff, industrial waste, and septic systems
Explain why contaminated groundwater is difficult and expensive to clean up
Describe how a plume of contamination spreads through an aquifer
Analyze steps communities can take to protect groundwater from contamination

sub_topics.name: Freshwater Resources and Water Management
sub_topics.short_description: Examining water supply challenges, water conservation, and strategies for managing limited freshwater resources.

sub_topics.name: Water Scarcity and Distribution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that freshwater is unevenly distributed globally and many regions face water scarcity.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between physical water scarcity and economic water scarcity
Identify regions on a world map that face severe water stress or scarcity
Analyze factors that make some regions water-poor despite adequate rainfall, such as lack of infrastructure
Compare per capita water availability in different countries and discuss implications

sub_topics.name: Water Use by Different Sectors
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how water is used for agriculture, industry, and domestic purposes in different regions.
example_tasks: Create a pie chart showing water use by sector (agriculture, industry, domestic) in the United States
Explain why agriculture accounts for about 70% of global freshwater use
Compare water use patterns in developed versus developing countries
Analyze the water footprint of different foods and products

sub_topics.name: Water Conservation and Efficiency
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying strategies individuals, communities, and industries can use to conserve water.
example_tasks: List ten specific actions individuals can take to conserve water at home
Explain technologies like drip irrigation that improve water efficiency in agriculture
Describe how water recycling and rainwater harvesting can supplement water supplies
Evaluate the effectiveness of different water conservation policies and incentive programs

sub_topics.name: Water Conflicts and Cooperation
sub_topics.short_description: Examining disputes over shared water resources and examples of international cooperation.
example_tasks: Describe a water conflict between countries or states, such as disputes over the Colorado River
Explain why shared river systems can cause tensions between upstream and downstream users
Identify examples of successful water-sharing agreements between countries
Analyze challenges of managing water resources that cross political boundaries

name: Ecosystems and Biomes
short_description: Students examine Earth's major terrestrial and aquatic biomes, understanding the relationships between climate, vegetation, wildlife, and human activities in different ecosystems around the world.

sub_topics.name: Ecosystem Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ecosystems as communities of living organisms interacting with their physical environment.

sub_topics.name: Biotic and Abiotic Factors
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between living (biotic) and non-living (abiotic) components of ecosystems.
example_tasks: List five biotic factors and five abiotic factors in a forest ecosystem
Explain how abiotic factors like sunlight, water, and temperature affect biotic factors in an ecosystem
Classify a list of ecosystem components as either biotic or abiotic
Analyze how changes in abiotic factors such as rainfall can impact the biotic community

sub_topics.name: Energy Flow and Food Webs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how energy flows through ecosystems from producers to consumers to decomposers.
example_tasks: Create a food web for a local ecosystem showing at least 10 organisms and their feeding relationships
Explain the role of producers, consumers, and decomposers in ecosystem energy flow
Describe how energy is lost as heat as it moves up trophic levels in a food chain
Analyze what would happen to a food web if a key species were removed from the ecosystem

sub_topics.name: Ecosystem Services
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the benefits humans receive from healthy ecosystems including clean air, water, and resources.
example_tasks: List five ecosystem services provided by forests and five provided by wetlands
Explain how ecosystem services have economic value even though they are often free
Describe how wetlands provide flood control and water filtration services
Analyze the consequences of ecosystem degradation for human communities

sub_topics.name: Major Terrestrial Biomes
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the characteristics, distribution, and biodiversity of Earth's major land biomes.

sub_topics.name: Tropical Rainforest Biome
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the climate, vegetation, wildlife, and threats facing tropical rainforests.
example_tasks: Describe the climate characteristics of tropical rainforests including temperature and precipitation patterns
Explain why tropical rainforests have the highest biodiversity of any terrestrial biome
Identify major tropical rainforest regions on a world map including the Amazon, Congo Basin, and Southeast Asia
Analyze threats to rainforests including deforestation for agriculture and logging

sub_topics.name: Temperate Forest Biome
sub_topics.short_description: Examining deciduous and coniferous temperate forests and their adaptations to seasonal climates.
example_tasks: Compare deciduous forests (trees lose leaves in fall) with evergreen coniferous forests
Explain adaptations of temperate forest plants and animals to seasonal changes
Identify temperate forest regions in eastern North America, Europe, and East Asia on a map
Describe how temperate forests have been affected by human settlement and agriculture

sub_topics.name: Grassland Biomes (Prairies, Savannas, Steppes)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding temperate grasslands and tropical savannas and their importance for agriculture and grazing.
example_tasks: Compare temperate grasslands (prairies, steppes) with tropical grasslands (savannas)
Explain why grasslands have few trees despite adequate rainfall in some areas
Identify major grassland regions including the Great Plains, African savanna, and Eurasian steppe
Analyze how most temperate grasslands have been converted to agricultural use

sub_topics.name: Desert Biome
sub_topics.short_description: Examining hot and cold deserts and adaptations of desert organisms to extreme aridity.
example_tasks: Describe the climate characteristics that define desert biomes (less than 10 inches annual rainfall)
Explain adaptations of desert plants and animals for conserving water and surviving extreme temperatures
Compare hot deserts like the Sahara with cold deserts like the Gobi Desert
Identify major desert regions on a world map and explain factors that create each desert

sub_topics.name: Taiga (Boreal Forest) and Tundra Biomes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the characteristics of high-latitude biomes with cold climates and short growing seasons.
example_tasks: Compare the taiga (boreal forest) with the tundra biome in terms of vegetation and climate
Explain adaptations of plants and animals to survive long, cold winters in taiga and tundra
Describe the permafrost layer in tundra regions and its ecological importance
Identify the circumpolar distribution of taiga and tundra in the Northern Hemisphere

sub_topics.name: Aquatic Ecosystems
sub_topics.short_description: Examining freshwater and marine ecosystems and their unique characteristics and inhabitants.

sub_topics.name: Freshwater Ecosystems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, and wetlands as freshwater habitats.
example_tasks: Compare the characteristics of standing water ecosystems (lakes, ponds) with flowing water ecosystems (rivers, streams)
Describe the different zones of a lake (littoral, limnetic, profundal) and organisms found in each
Explain the ecological importance of wetlands for water filtration, flood control, and biodiversity
Analyze threats to freshwater ecosystems including pollution, dam construction, and invasive species

sub_topics.name: Marine Ecosystems
sub_topics.short_description: Examining ocean zones, coral reefs, estuaries, and other saltwater ecosystems.
example_tasks: Describe the major zones of the ocean based on depth and light penetration (intertidal, neritic, oceanic)
Explain why coral reefs are called the 'rainforests of the sea' due to their high biodiversity
Compare the characteristics of estuaries (where rivers meet the ocean) with open ocean ecosystems
Analyze threats to marine ecosystems including overfishing, pollution, and ocean acidification

sub_topics.name: Biodiversity and Conservation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the importance of biodiversity and threats to species and ecosystems worldwide.

sub_topics.name: The Importance of Biodiversity
sub_topics.short_description: Examining genetic, species, and ecosystem diversity and why biodiversity matters.
example_tasks: Define biodiversity at three levels: genetic diversity, species diversity, and ecosystem diversity
Explain five reasons why biodiversity is important for ecosystems and human welfare
Compare biodiversity in tropical regions versus polar regions and explain the differences
Analyze how biodiversity provides resilience to ecosystems facing environmental changes

sub_topics.name: Threats to Biodiversity
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying major threats including habitat loss, invasive species, pollution, and climate change.
example_tasks: List and describe the major threats to biodiversity worldwide
Explain how habitat fragmentation affects species survival and ecosystem function
Describe how invasive species can disrupt ecosystems, using specific examples
Analyze the relationship between human population growth and biodiversity loss

sub_topics.name: Conservation Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Examining protected areas, endangered species laws, and conservation efforts to preserve biodiversity.
example_tasks: Describe the purpose of national parks, wildlife refuges, and other protected areas
Explain how the Endangered Species Act helps protect threatened and endangered species in the U.S.
Identify successful conservation programs such as the recovery of bald eagles or gray wolves
Evaluate the effectiveness of different conservation strategies including habitat preservation and captive breeding

sub_topics.name: Human Impacts on Ecosystems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how human activities affect natural ecosystems and examining paths toward sustainability.

sub_topics.name: Deforestation and Land Use Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding causes and consequences of forest clearing for agriculture, logging, and development.
example_tasks: Explain the main causes of deforestation in tropical and temperate regions
Describe environmental consequences of deforestation including soil erosion, habitat loss, and climate impacts
Analyze deforestation data for a region like the Amazon and create graphs showing trends over time
Evaluate sustainable forestry practices and reforestation efforts as solutions

sub_topics.name: Pollution Impacts on Ecosystems
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how air, water, and soil pollution affect ecosystem health and biodiversity.
example_tasks: Describe how eutrophication from nutrient pollution creates dead zones in aquatic ecosystems
Explain the effects of acid rain on forest and aquatic ecosystems
Analyze the impact of plastic pollution on marine ecosystems and wildlife
Evaluate the success of pollution reduction efforts like the Clean Air Act in restoring ecosystems

sub_topics.name: Sustainable Resource Use
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring practices that meet human needs while preserving ecosystems for future generations.
example_tasks: Define sustainability and explain why sustainable practices are necessary for long-term human welfare
Compare sustainable fishing practices with overfishing and its ecosystem consequences
Describe sustainable agriculture practices that protect soil health and biodiversity
Analyze your own ecological footprint and identify ways to reduce environmental impact

name: Population Geography
short_description: Students analyze patterns of human population distribution, demographic trends, population density, migration patterns, and factors influencing where people live and move.

sub_topics.name: Population Distribution and Density
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how population is spread unevenly across Earth and measuring population concentration.

sub_topics.name: World Population Distribution Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying regions of high and low population concentration and factors that influence distribution.
example_tasks: Identify the most densely populated regions of the world on a population density map including East Asia, South Asia, and Europe
Explain why certain areas like deserts, polar regions, and high mountains have very low population density
Analyze a world population distribution map to identify patterns such as clustering along coasts and rivers
Compare population distribution in the Northern versus Southern Hemisphere and explain the differences

sub_topics.name: Calculating and Comparing Population Density
sub_topics.short_description: Using population density formulas to compare how crowded different regions are.
example_tasks: Calculate the population density of three countries or cities given their population and land area
Explain the difference between arithmetic density and physiological density (people per arable land)
Compare the population densities of urban areas like Manhattan versus rural areas like Montana
Analyze why countries with similar population densities may have very different living conditions

sub_topics.name: Physical and Human Factors Affecting Distribution
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how climate, landforms, resources, economic opportunities, and history shape where people live.
example_tasks: List five physical factors and five human factors that influence population distribution
Explain why river valleys and coastal plains tend to have higher population densities than mountains
Analyze how access to water, fertile soil, and natural resources attracts population concentration
Evaluate how economic opportunities in cities draw population from rural areas

sub_topics.name: Demographic Transition and Population Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how birth rates, death rates, and population growth change as countries develop economically.

sub_topics.name: Birth Rates and Death Rates
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing crude birth rates, crude death rates, and natural increase rates to understand population growth.
example_tasks: Calculate the natural increase rate of a country given its birth rate and death rate
Compare birth rates and death rates in developed versus developing countries
Explain factors that influence birth rates including education, healthcare, and cultural values
Analyze trends in death rates and increasing life expectancy in different regions

sub_topics.name: Stages of the Demographic Transition Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the five stages of demographic transition from high birth and death rates to low rates.
example_tasks: Describe the characteristics of each stage of the demographic transition model in terms of birth rates, death rates, and population growth
Identify which stage of demographic transition different countries are in based on their demographic data
Explain why death rates decline before birth rates during demographic transition
Predict future population trends for countries in different stages of demographic transition

sub_topics.name: Population Pyramids and Age Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Reading and interpreting population pyramid graphs to understand age and gender distribution.
example_tasks: Interpret a population pyramid to determine whether a country has a young, aging, or balanced population
Compare population pyramids of developing countries (wide base) with developed countries (narrow base)
Explain what different pyramid shapes reveal about past and future population growth
Analyze how the age structure of a population affects economic and social planning

sub_topics.name: Migration Patterns and Processes
sub_topics.short_description: Examining why people migrate, types of migration, and the impacts of migration on origin and destination areas.

sub_topics.name: Push and Pull Factors of Migration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the factors that push people to leave places and pull them to new destinations.
example_tasks: List five push factors (reasons to leave) and five pull factors (reasons to move to a new place)
Explain how economic opportunities act as pull factors attracting migrants to certain regions
Analyze how conflict, persecution, and natural disasters serve as push factors forcing migration
Classify specific migration examples based on their push and pull factors

sub_topics.name: Types of Migration
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between voluntary and forced migration, and internal versus international migration.
example_tasks: Compare voluntary migration (moving by choice) with forced migration (refugees, internally displaced persons)
Explain the difference between internal migration (within a country) and international migration (across borders)
Describe rural-to-urban migration patterns and reasons people move from countryside to cities
Analyze historical examples of forced migration such as the transatlantic slave trade or refugee crises

sub_topics.name: Impacts of Migration
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the effects of migration on both the places people leave and the places they move to.
example_tasks: Describe positive and negative impacts of out-migration on origin communities (brain drain, remittances)
Analyze the effects of immigration on destination communities including cultural diversity and labor supply
Explain how remittances (money sent home) from migrants support families and economies in origin countries
Evaluate the challenges immigrants face in adapting to new places including language, employment, and discrimination

sub_topics.name: Migration Policies and Refugees
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding immigration laws, refugee policies, and international responses to migration.
example_tasks: Compare immigration policies of different countries ranging from restrictive to welcoming
Explain the legal definition of a refugee and how it differs from other types of migrants
Describe the role of international organizations like the UN High Commissioner for Refugees
Analyze a current migration crisis and evaluate different policy responses

sub_topics.name: Population Challenges and Planning
sub_topics.short_description: Examining overpopulation, aging populations, and strategies countries use to manage population issues.

sub_topics.name: Overpopulation and Resource Strain
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding concerns about rapid population growth straining resources, infrastructure, and environment.
example_tasks: Explain the concept of carrying capacity and how it relates to human populations
Describe challenges rapidly growing populations face including resource scarcity, unemployment, and environmental degradation
Analyze population growth rates in different regions and predict future challenges
Evaluate Malthusian theory about population growth outpacing food supply

sub_topics.name: Aging Populations in Developed Countries
sub_topics.short_description: Examining challenges of countries with declining birth rates and increasing elderly populations.
example_tasks: Describe demographic challenges facing countries like Japan and Italy with aging populations
Explain economic impacts of fewer working-age people supporting more retirees
Analyze how aging populations affect healthcare systems, pensions, and economic growth
Evaluate policy responses to aging populations such as raising retirement age or encouraging immigration

sub_topics.name: Population Policies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pro-natalist and anti-natalist policies governments use to influence population growth.
example_tasks: Compare anti-natalist policies (like China's former one-child policy) with pro-natalist policies (like France's family incentives)
Explain reasons governments implement population policies and their effectiveness
Analyze ethical concerns about government involvement in reproductive decisions
Evaluate the success of family planning programs in reducing population growth rates

name: Cultural Geography
short_description: Students explore the spatial dimensions of culture including language, religion, ethnicity, customs, and how cultural characteristics vary across regions and diffuse through space and time.

sub_topics.name: Elements of Culture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the components that make up culture including language, religion, social structures, and material culture.

sub_topics.name: Defining Culture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding culture as learned behaviors, beliefs, and practices shared by a group of people.
example_tasks: Define culture and explain how it differs from instinct or biology
List seven elements that anthropologists and geographers use to define culture
Explain how culture is learned and transmitted from one generation to the next
Compare material culture (physical objects) with non-material culture (ideas, beliefs, values)

sub_topics.name: Cultural Traits and Complexes
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying individual cultural traits and how they combine into cultural complexes and regions.
example_tasks: Define cultural trait and provide five examples from your own culture
Explain how related cultural traits combine to form a cultural complex (example: sports complex includes rules, equipment, stadiums)
Describe how cultural complexes define cultural regions like Latin America or the Middle East
Analyze how one cultural trait can have different meanings in different cultures

sub_topics.name: Language Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Examining the distribution of languages, language families, and the role of language in shaping cultural identity and regions.

sub_topics.name: World Language Families
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how languages are grouped into families based on common origins.
example_tasks: Identify the major language families including Indo-European, Sino-Tibetan, and Afro-Asiatic
Explain what it means for languages to belong to the same language family
Locate regions where different language families are dominant on a world map
Trace the relationship between English, Spanish, and Hindi as members of the Indo-European family

sub_topics.name: Language Diffusion and Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how languages spread through migration, conquest, and trade, and how they evolve over time.
example_tasks: Explain how English spread globally through British colonialism and American influence
Describe how languages change over time through borrowing words and adapting to new contexts
Analyze the spread of Spanish in the Americas following European colonization
Identify examples of lingua francas (common languages) used for communication between different groups

sub_topics.name: Language Diversity and Endangered Languages
sub_topics.short_description: Examining linguistic diversity and threats to minority languages around the world.
example_tasks: Explain why language diversity is important for cultural heritage and knowledge
Describe factors causing language endangerment and death including globalization and language shift
Identify regions with high linguistic diversity such as Papua New Guinea or parts of Africa
Evaluate efforts to preserve endangered languages through education and documentation

sub_topics.name: Religion Geography
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the spatial distribution of major world religions and their influence on cultural landscapes and practices.

sub_topics.name: Major World Religions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the beliefs, practices, and geographic distributions of major religions.
example_tasks: Identify and locate the hearths (origin regions) of Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, and Judaism on a world map
Compare the key beliefs and practices of two major world religions
Describe the geographic distribution of major religions and how it reflects historical diffusion patterns
Explain the difference between universalizing religions (seek converts) and ethnic religions (tied to specific groups)

sub_topics.name: Religious Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how religions spread through relocation diffusion and expansion diffusion.
example_tasks: Explain how Buddhism spread from India throughout Asia through missionary activity and trade
Describe the rapid expansion of Islam from Arabia across Africa, Asia, and Europe
Compare relocation diffusion (migration) with expansion diffusion (spreading through a population)
Analyze the spread of Christianity through Europe and then global colonization

sub_topics.name: Religion and the Cultural Landscape
sub_topics.short_description: Examining how religious beliefs shape architecture, land use, and cultural practices in different regions.
example_tasks: Identify examples of religious architecture such as mosques, temples, churches, and synagogues
Explain how religious beliefs influence dietary practices, dress, and daily routines
Describe sacred sites and pilgrimage destinations for different religions
Analyze how religious calendars and holidays vary across cultures

sub_topics.name: Religious Conflict and Cooperation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how religion can be a source of both unity and division in different regions.
example_tasks: Describe a region where religious differences have contributed to conflict (e.g., Northern Ireland, Israel/Palestine)
Explain factors beyond theology that contribute to religious conflicts including territory and resources
Identify examples of interfaith cooperation and tolerance in diverse societies
Analyze how religious diversity affects cultural and political dynamics in a region

sub_topics.name: Cultural Diffusion and Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the processes by which cultural traits spread from one place to another and how cultures change over time.

sub_topics.name: Types of Cultural Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between relocation, expansion, hierarchical, contagious, and stimulus diffusion.
example_tasks: Define and give examples of relocation diffusion (migration carrying culture) and expansion diffusion (spreading through a population)
Explain hierarchical diffusion where ideas spread from powerful/wealthy to less powerful people
Describe contagious diffusion where ideas spread rapidly through a population like a disease
Analyze how social media represents contagious diffusion of information and trends

sub_topics.name: Barriers to Cultural Diffusion
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying physical and cultural barriers that slow or prevent the spread of cultural traits.
example_tasks: Explain how physical barriers like mountains and oceans historically limited cultural diffusion
Describe how cultural barriers like language, religion, and political boundaries affect diffusion
Analyze how technology has reduced physical barriers but cultural barriers remain important
Evaluate the role of government censorship as a barrier to information diffusion

sub_topics.name: Acculturation and Assimilation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding processes of cultural change when different groups interact.
example_tasks: Define acculturation as cultural change resulting from contact between groups
Explain the difference between acculturation (adopting some traits) and assimilation (full adoption of new culture)
Describe examples of immigrant groups experiencing acculturation in the United States
Analyze factors that influence whether groups maintain cultural identity or assimilate

sub_topics.name: Cultural Regions and Cultural Landscapes
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying areas with shared cultural characteristics and how culture is reflected in the physical landscape.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Cultural Regions
sub_topics.short_description: Defining and mapping areas with common cultural traits such as language, religion, or ethnicity.
example_tasks: Define cultural region and explain how geographers determine regional boundaries
Identify major cultural regions of the world such as Latin America, Sub-Saharan Africa, East Asia
Explain why cultural region boundaries are often fuzzy and overlap rather than being precise lines
Map a cultural region in your own country based on shared characteristics like dialect or cuisine

sub_topics.name: Cultural Landscape Features
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing how culture shapes the visible landscape including architecture, land use, and settlement patterns.
example_tasks: Identify cultural landscape features such as building styles, agricultural patterns, and street layouts
Explain how religious beliefs influence landscape features like the orientation of buildings or presence of temples
Compare the cultural landscapes of different regions (e.g., New England villages vs. Spanish colonial towns)
Analyze photographs of landscapes to infer cultural characteristics of the people who shaped them

sub_topics.name: Sense of Place and Cultural Identity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how people develop attachments to places and how places reflect cultural identity.
example_tasks: Define sense of place and explain why certain locations have special meaning for individuals or groups
Describe how cultural identity is tied to specific places such as homelands or sacred sites
Analyze how place names reflect the cultural history of a region
Explain how globalization can threaten unique local cultures and sense of place

sub_topics.name: Folk Culture and Popular Culture
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between traditional local culture and widespread commercial culture and analyzing their diffusion.

sub_topics.name: Folk Culture Characteristics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding traditional practices with strong ties to specific places and slow rates of change.
example_tasks: Define folk culture and provide examples such as traditional clothing, music, or food
Explain how folk culture is passed down through families and local communities
Describe characteristics of folk housing styles reflecting local materials and climate
Analyze how isolation helps preserve folk culture but globalization threatens it

sub_topics.name: Popular Culture Characteristics
sub_topics.short_description: Examining mass-produced commercial culture that spreads quickly and lacks strong place ties.
example_tasks: Define popular culture and provide examples such as fast food, movies, and fashion trends
Explain how popular culture diffuses rapidly through mass media and technology
Compare how popular culture is experienced similarly across many places while folk culture varies locally
Analyze how corporations promote popular culture products worldwide through advertising

sub_topics.name: Cultural Homogenization and Diversity
sub_topics.short_description: Debating whether globalization creates more cultural uniformity or if local cultures adapt and persist.
example_tasks: Explain the concern that globalization creates cultural homogenization as local traditions disappear
Describe examples of resistance to cultural homogenization through local movements
Analyze how global brands adapt products to local tastes (glocalization)
Evaluate whether cultural diversity is declining or simply changing in the modern world

name: Urban Geography
short_description: Students examine urbanization processes, city structure and growth patterns, differences between urban and rural areas, and challenges facing cities in different parts of the world.

sub_topics.name: Urbanization Process
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the historical and ongoing shift of population from rural to urban areas worldwide.

sub_topics.name: Defining Urban Areas and Urbanization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what constitutes an urban area and measuring urbanization rates.
example_tasks: Define urban area and explain different criteria countries use to classify settlements as urban
Calculate the percentage of a country's population living in urban areas given population data
Compare urbanization levels in developed versus developing countries
Explain the difference between urbanization (increasing % urban) and urban growth (increasing city population)

sub_topics.name: Historical Urbanization Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Tracing urbanization from ancient cities through the Industrial Revolution to modern megacities.
example_tasks: Describe characteristics of early cities like Mesopotamian city-states and their limited size
Explain how the Industrial Revolution accelerated urbanization in Europe and North America
Compare urbanization timelines in developed countries (gradual over centuries) versus developing countries (rapid in decades)
Analyze data showing the dramatic increase in urban population worldwide over the past 200 years

sub_topics.name: Current Global Urbanization Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Examining rapid urbanization in developing countries and the growth of megacities.
example_tasks: Identify regions experiencing the fastest urbanization rates, particularly in Asia and Africa
Define megacity (population over 10 million) and identify major megacities worldwide
Explain push and pull factors driving rural-to-urban migration in developing countries
Analyze projections showing that most of the world's population will be urban by 2050

sub_topics.name: Urban and Rural Differences
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing characteristics, lifestyles, economic activities, and challenges in urban versus rural areas.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Urban Areas
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying defining features of cities including high density, diverse economy, and extensive infrastructure.
example_tasks: List characteristics that distinguish urban areas from rural areas including density, infrastructure, and economic activities
Explain how cities are characterized by high population density and diverse populations
Describe the dominance of secondary (manufacturing) and tertiary (service) economic sectors in urban areas
Analyze advantages cities offer such as job opportunities, services, and cultural amenities

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Rural Areas
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding features of rural areas including low density, agricultural focus, and closer community ties.
example_tasks: List characteristics of rural areas including low population density and agricultural land use
Explain how rural economies are often dominated by primary sector activities like farming, forestry, and mining
Describe advantages of rural living such as open space, nature access, and strong community bonds
Compare challenges facing rural areas including limited services, economic opportunities, and aging populations

sub_topics.name: Suburban Areas
sub_topics.short_description: Examining suburbs as transitional zones between cities and rural areas with distinct characteristics.
example_tasks: Define suburbs and explain their development, particularly in the United States after World War II
Describe characteristics of suburbs including lower density than cities but more development than rural areas
Explain factors that attracted families to suburbs including affordable housing, yards, and good schools
Analyze challenges suburbs face including car dependency, sprawl, and lack of urban amenities

sub_topics.name: City Structure and Models
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding patterns of land use within cities and geographic models that explain urban structure.

sub_topics.name: Urban Land Use Zones
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying common zones in cities including CBD, residential, industrial, and commercial areas.
example_tasks: Define Central Business District (CBD) and describe its characteristics including tall buildings and high land values
Identify residential, industrial, commercial, and public/institutional land uses on a city land use map
Explain why different land uses cluster in different parts of cities
Analyze how land use zones in your own city or a nearby city are distributed

sub_topics.name: Concentric Zone Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Burgess's model showing cities growing outward in rings from the CBD.
example_tasks: Draw and label the concentric zone model showing five zones from CBD to commuter zone
Explain assumptions of the concentric zone model including growth outward from the center
Describe characteristics of each zone including the transition zone and working-class residential zone
Analyze which cities might fit this model well and which would not, and explain why

sub_topics.name: Sector and Multiple Nuclei Models
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring alternative models showing how cities develop along transportation corridors or with multiple centers.
example_tasks: Draw and explain Hoyt's sector model showing how similar land uses extend outward along transportation lines
Describe Harris and Ullman's multiple nuclei model showing cities with multiple centers rather than one CBD
Compare the three urban models (concentric, sector, multiple nuclei) and when each applies best
Analyze a real city to determine which model or combination of models best explains its structure

sub_topics.name: Urban Challenges and Issues
sub_topics.short_description: Examining problems cities face including sprawl, traffic congestion, housing, inequality, and environmental issues.

sub_topics.name: Urban Sprawl
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the spread of low-density development into rural areas and its consequences.
example_tasks: Define urban sprawl and identify characteristics including low density and car-dependent development
Explain causes of sprawl including cheap land on city outskirts and preference for single-family homes
Describe negative effects of sprawl including loss of farmland, increased traffic, and infrastructure costs
Evaluate strategies to manage sprawl such as urban growth boundaries and smart growth policies

sub_topics.name: Transportation and Infrastructure Challenges
sub_topics.short_description: Examining traffic congestion, public transit needs, and infrastructure demands in growing cities.
example_tasks: Explain causes of traffic congestion in cities and how it affects quality of life
Compare the benefits and challenges of different transportation modes including cars, buses, and rail
Describe how cities can encourage public transit use and reduce car dependency
Analyze the infrastructure needs of rapidly growing cities in developing countries

sub_topics.name: Housing Affordability and Urban Inequality
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding housing shortages, affordability crises, and spatial patterns of wealth and poverty in cities.
example_tasks: Explain factors causing housing affordability problems in many cities including supply shortages and demand
Describe the formation of informal settlements (slums, favelas) in cities of developing countries
Analyze gentrification as a process where wealthier residents move into lower-income neighborhoods
Evaluate policies to address housing affordability and reduce urban inequality

sub_topics.name: Urban Environmental Issues
sub_topics.short_description: Examining air and water pollution, urban heat islands, and waste management in cities.
example_tasks: Describe the urban heat island effect where cities are warmer than surrounding rural areas
Explain sources of urban air pollution including vehicle emissions and industrial activities
Analyze challenges of providing clean water and sanitation in rapidly growing cities
Evaluate sustainable city initiatives such as green buildings, urban parks, and renewable energy

sub_topics.name: Global Cities and Urban Hierarchies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how cities function in a global economic system and vary in size and importance.

sub_topics.name: World Cities and Global Command Centers
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying major world cities that serve as centers of global finance, business, and culture.
example_tasks: Define world city (global city) as a center of international finance, business headquarters, and culture
Identify major world cities including New York, London, Tokyo, and others
Explain characteristics that make cities global command centers including stock exchanges and multinational headquarters
Analyze why world cities have disproportionate influence on the global economy and culture

sub_topics.name: Urban Hierarchy and Central Place Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how cities of different sizes provide different levels of goods and services.
example_tasks: Explain urban hierarchy as a ranking of cities from small towns to megacities
Describe central place theory's explanation of how cities of different sizes serve surrounding areas
Compare the number and spacing of small towns versus large cities in a region
